courseDescription: This course will explore why people believe conspiracy theories and why people become dedicated to religious cults or new religious movements, and will provide training in tools and strategies for examining truth claims of various groups.
Technical and Digital Skills: Researching conspiracy theories and religious cults
Using digital tools for examining truth claims
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding human psychology and belief systems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of belief systems and conspiracy theories
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions and debates on controversial topics

courseDescription: What is the meaning of life, and what role might the end of life play in living meaningfully? This course provides an introduction to philosophy and religious studies through an investigation of different views on death and the meaning of life from diverse cultures and identities. (Cross-listed with PHIL 150P)
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective articulation of philosophical and religious concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of religious perspective on life and death
Comparative analysis of different cultures and identities
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing thoughts and arguments in a cohesive manner

courseDescription: What ways of thinking, feeling, and acting are essentially human? This course focuses on some of the most influential and fascinating philosophical and religious accounts of human nature from diverse cultural perspectives. Topics may include the nature of human beings in relation to God, society, ethics, politics, knowledge, the environment, freedom, evolution, the mind, language, race, gender, and technology.  (Cross-listed with PHIL 155E)
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of the impact of technology on human nature
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of complex philosophical concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of philosophical and religious accounts
Analytical thinking on topics like ethics, politics, knowledge, the environment, freedom, evolution
Understanding and application of diverse cultural perspectives
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Taking a leadership role in group discussions
Organizing thoughts and theories on complex topics

courseDescription: Open only to students in the Honors College. A special honors section of REL 260G.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and debate on sensitive topics
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of religious and cultural narratives

courseDescription: Is love universal or culturally bound? Is sexual desire biologically driven or learned? This course provides an introduction to Philosophy and Religious Studies through an investigation of love, sex, and desire vis-a-vis ethical values and societal norms. (Cross-listed with PHIL 235E)
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and comparing different philosophical viewpoints

courseDescription: Television, film, and journalism play an influential role in introducing Muslim life to broad audiences. This course provides an introduction to the representation of Islam in news and popular culture over the past century. In examining the relationship between Muslims and media we will develop information literacy skills and learn how to critically evaluate and interpret these sources.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing representation of Islam in media

courseDescription: An investigation of the Hebrew Bible on the basis of Biblical criticism and research.  Attention is given to the cultural and historical background of these writings.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of cultural and historical background of Hebrew Bible
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and debate of Biblical interpretations
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of historical and cultural contexts

courseDescription: An investigation of New Testament literature and thought on the basis of Biblical criticism and research.  Attention is given to the religious and cultural background of early Christianity, particularly in late Judaism.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of religious and cultural backgrounds
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of religious and cultural context

courseDescription: The course will examine the Qur'an, the scripture of Islam, as well as other sacred texts such as the Hadith literature (sayings of Muhammad) and the Sira literature (accounts of Muhammad's life). This course will explore the role of these literatures in the faith, culture, and history of Islam. Our survey will include explorations of the history and reception of various texts, their literary and stylistic features, and various themes such as mystical, legal, modern, and feminist interpretations.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of different literary and stylistic features
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and debate on various themes
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of historical and cultural contexts

courseDescription: This course is a basic introduction to Judaism. We will explore the fundamental tenets of Jewish belief, examine primary expressions of Jewish ritual and practice, discuss the historical development of Judaism, and explore sacred texts, secular Yiddish texts, and contemporary issues confronting Jews and Judaism.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of Jewish rituals and practices
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion of contemporary issues in Judaism
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of secular Yiddish texts
Understanding and interpreting Jewish belief systems

courseDescription: A study of the Christian tradition, including its primary texts, historical development, intellectual tenets, and contributions to human culture.  Specific attention will be given to Christianity as a way of life.

A study of the Islamic tradition, including its primary texts, historical development, intellectual tenets, and contributions to human culture.  Specific attention will be given to Islam as a way of life.

This course introduces students to several key religious traditions originating in Asia, such as: Hindu traditions in India; Confucianism, Daoism, and popular religion in China, Buddhism and Shinto in Japan; and Buddhist traditions of China, Tibet, and Mongolia. Students will read and analyze primary sources in English translation. By examining artifacts from literature, art, and poetry, students will also learn about cultural history. Throughout the course, we will be employing hermeneutical methods in the field of religions studies, such as methods of comparisons.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analyzing literature, art, and poetry as artifacts
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussing and comparing different religious traditions
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Employing hermeneutical methods in the field of religions studies
Methods of comparisons in religious studies
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing information from various religious traditions

courseTitle: African and African American Religious Traditions
courseDescription: This course surveys key historic and contemporary religions and socio-religious ideas that help shape African and African American life, culture and practices. It also reflects on culture and practice to discover ways in which lived experience shapes religious thought and practice.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Reflection and interpretation of lived experiences

courseDescription: An intensive study of the basic teachings of Hinduism as manifested in its sacred writings.
A study of the origin, historical development, and contemporary status of Buddhism, in terms of its religious and philosophical elements and its influence in Asian cultures.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding and interpreting religious and philosophical texts
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and debate of philosophical concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of religious and philosophical concepts

courseDescription: The advanced study of selected topics designed to permit qualified students to work on subjects that, because of their specialized nature, may not be taught regularly.  These courses will appear in the course schedule booklet and will be more fully described in information distributed to all academic advisors.

The advanced study of selected topics designed to permit qualified students to work on subjects that, because of their specialized nature, may not be taught regularly. These courses will appear in the course schedule and will be more fully described in information distributed to all academic advisors.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and debate on complex topics
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Interpretation of historical and contextual information

courseDescription: This course explores the shifting constructions of gender and sexuality in Muslim communities from the early period until the present, considering feminism, patriarchy, gender identity, masculinity, femininity, homosexuality, heteronormativity, and transgender people.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of gender and sexuality constructs
Evaluation of cultural norms and biases

courseDescription: This course will provide students with an introduction to Native American philosophies with a focus on issues of identity, genocide, personhood, gender, sovereignty, and decolonization. Topics will be approached though a consideration of Native American philosophical methodologies and Native views regarding metaphysics, epistemology, and ethics. (Cross-listed with PHIL 451)
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of historical events and their impact

courseTitle: Tibet, Happiness, and this Precious Life
courseDescription: Throughout this course, students will examine Tibetan texts and artifacts that address the meaning of happiness and the human condition. The course covers the indigenous religion Bön; the four main Tibetan Buddhist traditions (Nyingma, Sakya, Kagyu, and Geluk), Islam in Tibet, and contemporary social issues, such as gender, identity politics, and the use of social media.
Technical and Digital Skills: Analysis of Tibetan texts and artifacts
Understanding of social media impact on contemporary issues
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and interpretation of Tibetan Buddhist traditions and Islam in Tibet
Understanding and articulating concepts related to gender and identity politics
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation and interpretation of religious texts
Analysis of societal issues through a religious and cultural lens

courseDescription: The advanced study of selected topics designed to permit qualified students to work on subjects that, because of their specialized nature, may not be taught regularly.  These courses will appear in the course schedule and will be more fully described in information distributed to all academic advisors.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion and debate of specialized topics

courseDescription: The advanced study of selected topics designed to permit qualified students to work on subjects that, because of their specialized nature, may not be taught regularly. These courses will appear in the course schedule and will be more fully described in information distributed to all academic advisors.
Technical and Digital Skills: Note-taking and information organization using digital tools
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of religious texts and theories
Forming coherent arguments based on research

courseDescription: Independent reading and study of a topic to be selected under the direction of an instructor. Conferences and papers as appropriate.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of religious texts and theories

courseDescription: Independent reading and study of a topic to be selected under the direction of an instructor. Conferences and papers as appropriate.

This course explores the shifting constructions of gender and sexuality in Muslim communities from the early period until the present, considering feminism, patriarchy, gender identity, masculinity, femininity, homosexuality, heteronormativity, and transgender people.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of historical and contemporary cultural trends
Understanding and interpretation of gender identity issues

courseDescription: This course will provide students with an introduction to Native American philosophies with a focus on issues of identity, genocide, personhood, gender, sovereignty, and decolonization. Topics will be approached though a consideration of Native American philosophical methodologies and Native views regarding metaphysics, epistemology, and ethics. (Cross-listed with PHIL 551)
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and respect for diverse views and cultures
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding and analysis of historical events and their impacts

courseTitle: Tibet, Happiness, and this Precious Life
courseDescription: Throughout this course, students will examine Tibetan texts and artifacts that address the meaning of happiness and the human condition. The course covers the indigenous religion Bön; the four main Tibetan Buddhist traditions (Nyingma, Sakya, Kagyu, and Geluk), Islam in Tibet, and contemporary social issues, such as gender, identity politics, and the use of social media.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding the use of social media in contemporary society
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discussion of sensitive topics such as religion and identity politics
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of various religious traditions and social issues
Analytical reading of religious and historical texts
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading discussions on complex social issues

courseDescription: The advanced study of selected topics designed to permit qualified students to work on subjects that, because of their specialized nature, may not be taught regularly.  These courses will appear in the course schedule and will be more fully described in information distributed to all academic advisors.

The advanced study of selected topics designed to permit small groups of qualified students to work on subjects of mutual interest which, due to their specialized nature, may not be offered regularly. These courses will appear in the course schedule, and will be more fully described in information distributed to all academic advisors.
Independent reading and study of a topic to be selected under the direction of an instructor. Conferences and papers as appropriate.
Independent reading and study of a topic to be selected under the direction of an instructor. Conferences and papers as appropriate.
Independent reading and study of a topic to be selected under the direction of an instructor. Conferences and papers as appropriate.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Conveying study findings in written papers
